title: MLB DFS Plays: Thursday 9/26
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We’ll take a comprehensive look across the DFS industry to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

We will be looking at the five-game main slate starting at 7:05 ET.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Zack Wheeler - NY Mets (vs. Miami)

This is an abbreviated five-game evening slate, and I’m not looking to get sneaky at pitcher. Wheeler is the most expensive hurler in the player pool while noticing a price increase after allowing just one earned run in each of his past five starts. He’ll step into the best possible matchup against a Miami offense that ranks near the bottom in every crucial hitting category. You could look towards Aaron Civale or Sean Manaea in tournaments, but Wheeler is the obvious cash game choice tonight.

Also Consider: Sean Manaea, Aaron Civale

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Carlos Santana - Cleveland (at Chicago White Sox)

White Sox RHP Dylan Cease has been surprisingly good lately, but tonight’s date with the Indians represents a tougher test than his last two against Seattle and Detroit respectively. In other words, Cease’s .381 wOBA split to left-handed bats could be exposed, and Santana is a prime candidate to make that happen. A Cleveland stack of Santana, Jose Ramirez, and Francisco Lindor (plus a few others) is firmly in play tonight.

Also Consider: Matt Olson, Pete Alonso

SECOND BASE

Aledmys Diaz - Houston (at LA Angels)

Story continues

The Astros plan on resting most of their regular starters, so Diaz should step into a premium lineup spot. The matchup is inspiring while facing Angels’ RHP Jaime Barria, who carries a vulnerable .384 wOBA split to right-handed bats. Diaz is swinging a confident bat as well, picking up nine hits with one homer, six runs, five RBIs, and a steal over his past five games. Needless to say, this is an excellent spot to continue to his heater.

Also Consider: Jurickson Profar, Ian Happ

THIRD BASE

Jose Ramirez - Cleveland (at Chicago White Sox)

Ramirez missed a month of action with a broken hand, but he seems healthy after smacking three homers with eight RBIs in two games since rejoining the lineup. The Cleveland switch-hitter will look to keep the momentum against White Sox RHP Cease and his aforementioned .381 wOBA split to left-handed bats. Don’t be surprised if Jose comes through for the third straight game in this series.

Also consider: Matt Chapman, Abraham Toro

SHORTSTOP

Andrelton Simmons - LA Angels (vs. Houston)

Let me start this write-up by acknowledging that Francisco Lindor and Marcus Semien are very strong plays in this slate. However, both of them are extremely expensive as well, so I’ll outline a cheaper shortstop to help the rest of your lineup mesh. Andrelton Simmons will hold the platoon advantage over Houston LHP Wade Miley, and the veteran southpaw has struggled after allowing 18 earned runs through 11 innings over his past five starts. In fact, Miley has only completed more than one inning in two of those five appearances...that’s how bad he’s been. Simmons and company are definitely in play while the Houston lefty tries to figure things out.

Also Consider: Francisco Lindor, Marcus Semien

OUTFIELD

Yasiel Puig - Cleveland (at Chicago White Sox)

Puig is a right-handed bat, so he’ll miss out on the .381 wOBA split (to LHB) of Cease. However, the trade deadline acquisition has been doing his part to keep Cleveland in the playoff picture, racking up 15 hits with five doubles, seven RBIs, and two stolen bases over his past eight games. Puig can do it all, and he’s a streaky hitter who has clearly found his groove. Go ahead and look towards him on DFS sites that haven’t fully adjusted for his recent performances.

Michael Conforto - NY Mets (vs. Miami)

Speaking of underpriced players with respect to recent performances, Conforto has outpaced his mid-range salary with eight hits, three homers, and eight RBIs over his past three games. The Mets carry a high-end scoring projection (alongside OAK, CLE, and HOU) while facing Miami RHP Jordan Yamamoto. The Marlins’ rookie is battling back from the injured list, and he allowed four or more earned runs in six of seven games prior to that. In other words, there’s an opportunity for the Mets to post some runs here, and Conforto has been the main source of that lately.

Also consider: Kyle Schwarber, Oscar Mercado, Franmil Reyes, Brandon Nimmo, Ramon Laureano, Jake Marisnick (punt)
